H0.text: Fish are what eagles are most likely adapted to eat with their strong, sharp beaks.

H1.text: Eggs are what eagles’ strong, sharp beaks are most likely adapted for eating.

H2.text: Worms are what eagles are most likely adapted to eat with their strong, sharp beaks.

H3.text: Flowers are what eagles with strong, sharp beaks are most likely adapted to eat.

A4.text: Birds of prey or predatory birds, also known as raptors, are hypercarnivorous bird species that actively hunt and feed on other vertebrates (mainly mammals, reptiles and smaller birds).

A5.text: Their diets consist mainly of fish, aquatic birds, and small mammals.

A6.text: The African crowned eagle occasionally views human children as prey

A7.text: Some fossil evidence indicates large birds of prey occasionally preyed on prehistoric hominids

A9.text: Carnivory was a natural transition from insectivory for medium and large tetrapods, requiring minimal adaptation

A10.text: The beak, bill, or rostrum is used for eating, preening, manipulating objects, killing prey, fighting, probing for food, courtship and feeding young.

A11.text: Birds have acute eyesight—raptors have vision eight times sharper than humans—thanks to higher densities of photoreceptors in the retina.
